head.title: Foster Deal to Buy Beringer Puts Other Wineries in Play

hedline.hl1: Foster Deal to Buy Beringer Puts Other Wineries in Play

abstract.p: Foster's Brewing Group's $1.14 billion acquisition of Beringer Wine Estates Holdings is expected to prompt a new wave of consolidation among California's premium wineries; analysts and industry executives say deal effectively puts the ownership of significant independent winemakers in play; offer comes on heels of news that Vincor International of Canada is buying R H Phillips for $92 million (M)

block.p: The Foster's Brewing Group's $1.14 billion acquisition of Beringer Wine Estates Holdings is likely to prompt a new wave of consolidation among California's premium wineries, analysts and industry executives said today. The deal, they said, effectively puts the ownership of significant independent winemakers in play.

News of the offer for Beringer by Foster, the Australian beer and wine company, came a day after another California wine producer, R. H. Phillips, said it would be purchased by Vincor International of Canada for $92 million.

The Foster's Brewing Group's $1.14 billion acquisition of Beringer Wine Estates Holdings is likely to prompt a new wave of consolidation among California's premium wineries, analysts and industry executives said today. The deal, they said, effectively puts the ownership of significant independent winemakers in play.

News of the offer for Beringer by Foster, the Australian beer and wine company, came a day after another California wine producer, R. H. Phillips, said it would be purchased by Vincor International of Canada for $92 million.

Other independent winemakers that could become takeover targets include Kendall-Jackson, Robert Mondavi and Sutter Home. Kendall-Jackson, considered a likely candidate for an initial public offering, had been in talks with Beringer about a possible merger, but the talks broke off last week, an executive close to the winery said, because of conditions raised by Jess Jackson, Kendall-Jackson's founder.

In acquiring Beringer, Foster is buying the oldest operating winery in the Napa Valley of California, with 10,200 acres of vineyards. Beringer -- which over the years has grown well beyond its onetime boutique-winery status -- had sales of $700 million in the fiscal year that ended in June. In addition to Beringer labels, its brands include Chateau St. Jean, Souverain and Napa Ridge.
Foster already owns several leading Australian winemakers, and in February, it bought Windsor Vineyards in the Sonoma Valley of California, the No. 2 direct seller of wine in the United States.

Discussing the acquisition of Beringer, Jean-Michelle Valette, a wine industry consultant and former president of Franciscan Vineyards, said, ''It's a bellwether deal,'' and adding: ''While there were half a dozen premium wine companies that had all attained the same scale over time, all of a sudden you now have a clearly dominant player, with global reach and distribution in a number of significant markets. I think it's going to cause a big scramble among the others.''
Shares of Beringer rose $10.25 today, to $55.31. Robert Mondavi added $1.13, to $40. Class A shares of Canandaigua Brands, of Fairport, N.Y., were up $2.19, to $53.81.
